cropSuitability.recommendation: Wheat is highly suitable for loamy soil during Rabi season. The well-drained, fertile loamy soil provides excellent root development and nutrient retention for wheat cultivation.
Rice is ideal for clay soil during Kharif season. Clay soil retains water well, which is perfect for rice cultivation that requires standing water.
Groundnut and watermelon are suitable for sandy soil in summer. Sandy soil provides good drainage and prevents waterlogging during hot weather.
Cotton and sugarcane thrive in black soil during Kharif season. Black soil's high water retention and nutrient content support these crops well.
Millets and pulses are well-suited for red soil in Rabi season. These crops can tolerate the slightly acidic nature and lower fertility of red soil.
Maize and sugarcane are excellent choices for alluvial soil during Kharif. The fertile, well-drained alluvial soil supports high-yielding crops.

fertilizerAdvice.recommendation: Apply urea (46-0-0) at 120 kg/ha in split doses. Sandy soil has low nitrogen retention, so frequent small applications prevent nutrient loss through leaching.
Use DAP (18-46-0) at 100 kg/ha before transplanting, followed by urea at 80 kg/ha after 3 weeks. Clay soil retains nutrients well, allowing for larger applications.
Apply NPK (19-19-19) at 150 kg/ha at sowing, followed by urea at 60 kg/ha during flowering. Cotton requires balanced nutrition throughout its growth cycle.
Use SSP (Single Super Phosphate) at 200 kg/ha and muriate of potash at 50 kg/ha. Groundnut fixes nitrogen naturally but needs phosphorus and potassium.
Apply NPK (12-32-16) at 125 kg/ha at sowing. Loamy soil's good nutrient retention allows for single basal application for barley.
Use urea at 150 kg/ha in three splits: 1/3 at sowing, 1/3 at knee-high stage, 1/3 at tasseling. Maize has high nitrogen requirements during rapid growth phases.
Apply NPK (19-19-19) at 200 kg/ha in multiple doses: 50% at transplanting, 25% at flowering, 25% at fruit development. Tomatoes need continuous nutrition.

irrigationAdvice.recommendation: Irrigate daily with light watering (15-20mm). Sandy soil drains quickly, especially in summer heat. Use drip irrigation to minimize water loss and maintain consistent moisture.
Maintain 2-5cm standing water throughout the growing season. Clay soil's water retention is perfect for rice cultivation. Drain fields 10 days before harvest.
Irrigate every 15-20 days with 50-60mm water. Critical stages: crown root initiation, tillering, flowering, and grain filling. Avoid overwatering in loamy soil.
Irrigate every 10-12 days during flowering and boll development. Black soil retains moisture well, but cotton needs consistent water during critical growth phases.
Irrigate every 7-10 days with 25-30mm water. Red soil drains moderately; groundnut needs consistent moisture for pod development, especially during summer.
Reduce irrigation frequency by 30-40% compared to summer. Winter's lower evaporation rate means less frequent watering. Monitor soil moisture to avoid overwatering.
Irrigate every 7-10 days with heavy watering (75-100mm). Sugarcane is a water-intensive crop. Alluvial soil's good drainage prevents waterlogging issues.
